Data type

　TJS2 has no "type" for variables, but it has types internally. Rather than having no type, types are handled automatically / dynamically.
　Internal types include void, integer, real, string, object, and octet column types.

void

　void means nothing (different from JavaScript). The variable just declared is void.
　Use the === (identification) operator to compare between void.
　The typeof operator returns "void" for this.

Integer type

　TJS2 can handle 64-bit integers as integer types. Integers are usually treated as signed integers, with the only exception that the >>> handles unsigned integers.
　The typeof operator returns "Integer" for this.

Real type

　TJS2 can handle 64-bit precision real numbers (double precision real numbers) as real numbers.
　The typeof operator returns "Real" for this.

String type

　TJS2 can handle zero-terminated strings with no length restrictions. A zero-terminated string means to treat the string assuming that the string ends with \0.
　The character code handles wide characters (usually UNICODE), but whether it is a 16-bit wide character or a 32-bit wide character depends on the environment in which TJS2 was compiled. For example, it is 16bit on Windows, but 32bit on Solaris and Linux.
　The typeof operator returns "String" for this.

Object type

　An object type is a type that holds objects. In addition to objects allocated by the new operator, functions, classes, property objects, etc. are all object types.
　The typeof operator returns "Object" for this.

　Unlike TJS and JavaScript, the object type of TJS2 has a pointer to the object itself and a pointer to the object that is the context in which it is to be used. I am. The operator that changes this context part is the incontextof operator.

Octet sequence type

　The octet sequence type handles 8-bit data strings (octet sequence type). This is mainly for handling binary data.
　The typeof operator returns "Octet" for this.
